div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: WADY KOM OMBO COMPANY.
div.p: Sir Ernest Consol is very interested in the promotion of one of the most important reclamation schemes ever undertaken in Egypt. The Wady Kotu Ombo Company began its operations in 1903 and there is every pros pert of its becoming one of the soundest land conquîmes in the country. The following interesting account of the work appears in the "Times"

The remarkable reclamation scheme in progress at Kom Ombo, Upper Egypt, illustrates us much in its differences as in its points of similarity the practice of the many similar enterprises which are transforming the country'. The great majority of these are in the Delta. It is important to realize that this for some time to come must be even more than at present the seat of important engineering and agricultural activity. The Government's decision, made known on the late Sir Benjamin Baker's pronouncement for the raising of the Assuan dam, leaves no doubt that to the Delta will be applied the whole of the increased volume of water which about two years hence will begin to become available and augment in increasing ratio until the maximum surplus expected from the dam is reached, with the completion of the work of super-elevation. New enterprises in Upper Egypt are therefore bound to be at a disadvantage' as compared with lower Egypt for some few years, except in so far as provided for by the new Esneh barrage, water being the arbiter of engineering destinies and all others in this country. The development of Kom Ombo is, however, of sufficiently long standing to be independent of these considerations. The distinctive peculiarity of Kom Ombo, apart from its remote situation in Upper Egypt, 40 miles south of Assuan, consists in the fact that the plain, or "wadi," lies at about 23 mètres above Nile level. Reclamation has, therefore, to be carried out partly by a reversal of the methods usual in Lower Egypt, where the land lies low as compared with the Nile, and where, therefore, systems of drainage are the necessary components of canalization. The general principles underlying the operations are, however, essentially the same as on the Delta fields of reclamation.

Work at Kom Ombo commenced towards 1903 by the laying 6f a branch line from the Government railway to the river for the conveyance of material. Though, the preliminary difficulties in starting the works were great as regards both labour, climatic conditions, and manufactured material, such materials as lime, bricks, stone, and sand were found or*made on the spot. During the erection of the pumps and workshops at the Nile - carried out entirely by manual labour, a fact that speaks volumes for the Arab "reises," or foremen, who had crank shafts weighing 13 tons to handle—surveys were taken over the plain and the chief irrigation scheme was drawn up. The main pumping station is wholly constructed of reinforced concrete. The engines are carried on concrete blocks, the condensers, clarance pumps, and steam traps being placed on the basement. Though the pumps stand at a level of 86 60, high Nile has been known to reach R.L 90.60, and the pumps are submerged for a great part of the year. It follows that a heavy upward water pressure is exerted on the floor of the pumping station. The engines are of horizontal direct-acting tripleexpansion condensing type, working at a pressure of 13 atmospheres superheated steam. The main pump is a turbine centrifugal pump with side inlets and bottom discharge. The boilers, ten in number, are of French "Elephant

type, fitted with special grates for burning sugar-cane waste; they are also equipped with Green's economizers and super heaters. The four boilers for the subsidiary pumps are water-tube, Babcock-Wilcox type, and work under forced draught. The mains, which are painted inside and out with sideres - then, ascend abruptly for the first 40 mètre*, rising gently for the remaining 460 mètres until they discharge into the reservoir. The latter, constructed of armoured concrete, is of horseshoe shape, and Mr. A.H. Illuminer, the superintending engineer of the whole of the reclamation works, to whom the writer is indebted for the particulars recorded in this account, considers that probably this shape has allowed the expansion and contraction to operate so freely. The steel culvert, constructed on a sand foundation to neutralize the swelling of the earth when moistened, commences at the reservoir and continues for about 1,500 mètres until the canal is well established on the high level of the plain. Riveting was done by hand and caulking by pneumatic tools; an attempt was made at pneumatic riveting, but the Arab workmen, Mr. Plummer states, could never manage it successfully. The same trouble, but in a more acute form, was experienced by Messrs. Sir William Arrol and Co. in the building of Rodah bridge at Cairo. The culvert as a whole is an interesting example of skillful methods applied to counteract peculiar climatic conditions. One thousand two hundred and fifty tons of steel were used in the work. With a clay shade temperature of I15deg. F. and cold nights the expansion and contraction were enormous, ends of sections rising suddenly 20cm. and 30cm. in a night. Bands of one mètre wide were riveted on the ends of sections as they enter the masonry. Each band slides in and out on rails let into the masonry, the joint being kept tight by tarred rope packing enclosed between semi-circular angle irons ; the weight of the water keeps the canal floating on the packing. The culvert terminates in a brickwork regulator, from which the main canal, with a bed width of eight mètres, traverses the "wadi," feeding secondary canals each commanding from 400 to 3,500 acres. Mr. Plummer estimates that from 7,000 to 9,000 cubic mètres of water are required to wash an acre. Experience has fortunately shown that, contrary to anticipation, the salts do not rise to the surface again. The nitrates are, of course, unavoidably dissolved from the surface soil with the remaining salts, and require to be restored to the land in the form of manure.

As soon as the land is ready for cultivation, ploughing is performed by steam ploughs and levelling machines, and, owing to the flatness of the country, good results are obtained. Threshing is also successfully done by steam. Reclamation so far has been effected on 12,000 acres, nearly all of which area is rented. Com crops grow splendidly; cotton, after indifferent results two seasons ago, is expected to be a success this year. Sugar-cane has been most successful, and is proved to have taken no more, if not less, water than in middle Egypt, while it ripens more quickly at Kom Ombo. To attract population, villages built in stone have been placed at various points over the estate; shops, with a market as well as stores, a mosque, and schools have been erected. With a free flow of water everywhere the people are prosperous and contented, and on account of the steam pumping system of irrigation they are not forced to keep cattle for raising water- Light railways, of 12 kilo, rails and 60em. gauge, are lying put down all over the estate, and repairing shops and com mills are already erected. A curious circumstance that taxed the resources of the superintending engineer was the swelling of the soif when water was applied to it. The whole "wadi" has risen from the effects of the water. The walls of the first buildings and regulators erected split in the majority of cases through the disturbance to their foundations, and the whole of the hanks and bed level of the main canal required to he raised to suit the altered contours of the land.

div.head: Rest Houses.
div.p: The Government are about to construct a rest house and district engineer's office at Ibshan, in the Zifta Circle of Irrigation.

div.head: Passports
div.p: The number of persons who have obtained passports for the purpose of pissing the summer out of Egypt, amounts up to date to 3,020.

div.head: Hashish Dens.
div.p: A very successful seizure was carried out at Gamalieh recently and the usual steps taken for the punishment of the offenders, who are under arrest

div.head: The Plague
div.p: During the last twenty-four hours a new case of plague has been reported at Port Said, as also one death out of hospital at Assiout. There now remain 27 cases under treatment

div.head: The Cattle Plague
div.p: The Minister of the Interior has published a pamphlet which contains the decree for the cattle plague and several instructions for its treat meut and diagnosis. This pamphlet will be distributed to all the omdehs.

div.head: A Mouthy Firs
div.p: A tire broke out yesterday in a glass magazine, in the Mousky, Cairo. The fire engines worked hard for three hours before they could extinguish it. The fire destroyed property to the value of £f,500. The magazine is insured for £3,000.

div.head: Polytechnic School
div.p: The first year students of the Polytechnic School of Cain) are visiting Alexandria to study the technical works of the harbour and the Mahmoudieh Canal. The second and third year students will go to Kom Ombo to study the irrigation of Upper Egypt.

div.head: Dredger Leaves for Portsmouth
div.p: The Admiralty dredger "St. Giles" left Alexandria yesterday afternoon, after having been inspected by Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, for Portsmouth. She is under command of Captain J. Maclaren and will call on her way home at Malta and Gibraltar. The "St. Giles" came to Alexandria on August 10, 19.05 for the dredging of the new pass.

div.head: Companies in Egypt
div.p: A very useful and complete list of the companies established in Egypt has been issued by the British Chamber of Commerce. As a book of reference it is of a great value, and for each company it gives the date of establishment, objects, debentures, dividends paid, names of directors, and highest and lowest prices between duly 1, 1906 and March 31, 1907.

div.head: Typewriting Competition
div.p: At the recent typewriting competition which was held at Pavia, Italy, (on the 19th and 20th ult.) the Yost carried off the first prize in the hors concours" competition. This was a special test for extraordinary speed and wasentitled "hors concours." Mr. Warren, who worked the machine, accomplished the remarkable performance of doings 1,881 taps on the keys in three minutes oi at rate of about 175 short words & minute.

div.head: A Serious Accident.
div.p: On Saturday morning about 10 o'clock, Ibrahim, son of Mohammed Boy Choubaki, living with his. parents on a dahabeah near the Pont des Anglais at Ghezireh, was amusing -himself by firing at passing birds with a saloon rifle. Unfortunately shot wounded the son of the servant of the family named Ibrahim aged 12 years, rather seriously in the throat and the doctors offer very little hope of the boys recovery.

div.head: The French Fete
div.p: The fourteenth of July will only be marked in Alexandria by a reception at the French consulate, all celebrations having been cancelled owing to the misfortunes in the South France. In Cairo, however, there will be the usual festivities, for which the Esbekieh gardens will be the centre. The Gardet troop will give a free performance, to which the ministers, high officials, and diplomatic corps will be invited. Officers of the Egyptian Army and Army of Occupation will be admitted to the gardens without card,' if in uniform. The decoration of the gardens has been entrusted to Messrs. Beato'and Frigenti.

div.head: Khédivial Law School.
div.p: The resignation of M. Lambert is much commented on in the local French Press, as it is declared that the post given to Mr. Hill was reserved by a Frenchman in consequence of the verbal agreement between Lord Cromer and M. Cogordan, formerly French Diplomatic Agent at Cairo. On the other hand, the "Progrès" says that the appointment is in accord with the agreement of 1891 between the Egyptian and French Governments that in the event of there being no acceptable Egyptian or English candidate aFrench would be appointed. The resignation of Mr. Lambert was, it appears, due to Mr. Dunlop requesting him to retard his leave for a few days.

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS
Bourse and Banking Co. The Committee's Action
div.p: The Bourse was better to day owing to the rally in London.

The Committee of the Alexandria Stock and Sharebrokers Association will probably issue circular to the effect that all dealings in the Bourse and Banking Company, ordinary shares, will be compensated at par. It is presumed that clients will have to submit to this as according to the contract notes it is stipulated that clients must conform to all the decisions of the Committee:—

"Le present contrat est soumis à toutes les clauses et conditions énoncées dans les statut et règlements de l'Association des Courtiers en valeurs instituée le 1er Août 1902. Statua et Règlements dont les contractants déclarent avoir pleine et entière connaissance en s'engageant à s'y conformer. "
No decision has been arrived as to what is to be done in the ease of the founders shares which will probably be issued in November.

Supporters of the policy of the Committee state that there is a precedent for this extraordinary decision inasmuch as the Paris Bourse some years ago divided to compensate the dealings in the shares of the Union Générale at one thousand francs when the market value was only a hundred francs and clients and brokers lm«l to submit to this.
The highest price touched by. the ordinary shares of the Bourse and Banking Company was 2 3.16—2 1/4, The founders touched £31-32.

It is considered that the above system of compensation is the only way out of the difficulties as otherwise, if a failure occurs, there will be very little hopes if the creditors receiving anything at all.
This step requires serious consideration and we will discuss it in an approaching issue.
All the rumours in the local Press as to the present prospects of the Cassa di Sconto's situation are illusory, as no opinion can lie arrived at until the balance sheet is drawn up.
The members of the board of directors of the Cassa are on their way from Europe to be present at the General Meeting.
A Cairo correspondent writes :—

The attitude of the greater part of till inhabitants of Alexandria and Cairo, who happen to have come within the influence of the present wave of financial depression, appears to be unduly pessimistic and they're under the delusion that because they have been badly hit by the fall in prices, therefore the future prosperity of the country is irretrievably compromised. This exaggerated gloominess flatters their self- importance for it gives their own misfortunes an air of being only part and parcel of some universal calamity. Yet the country as a whole was never more prosperous, as the customs returns show beyond any doubt. The price of agricultural land was never better maintained. The cotton outlook was never more cheerful. The present crisis merely the normal result of over speculation, the outcome of a long continued spell of extraordinary prosperity.

The quotations of many first class securities may go lower. There may be many more smashes. The revelations as to the way which some concerns have been conducted may lie so scandalous, as to throw discredit in the eyes of Europe on the ways of conducting business in Egypt. Such concomitants of a crash are inevitable. There is, however, not the slightest reason for thereby holding that the commercial and financial welfare of entire country is permanently jeopardized. It is indeed a matter for congratulation that the crisis has corne at a lucky moment when the Situation was unhampered by difficulties arising from the political situation or nervousness as to the cotton prospects. If the slump had not begun in the early part of February the postponement would only have led to a far more aggravated position than even that which is noir prevailing, tor numbers of new companies would have been floated and over-speculation would have gone merrily onwards until we were awakened to a more grievous day of reckoning than that wo now have to face. Amidst the prevailing gloom some sanguine people base their hopes that a way out of this slough of despond may be made for Egypt by Sir Finest Cassel. Although that great financier is much interested in Egypt there is no reason for jumping to the conclusion that he will therefore^ play the part of a guardian angel to the Bourses of Alexandria and Cairo. The state of the London, Paris and Berlin Stock Exchanges do not give much ground for hoping for material assistance at the present time. The Egyptian Bourse will have to work out its own salvation. After the present acute fit of financial indigestion induced by over speculation comes to an end we shall doubtless be sadder but at any rate wiser, and will look back with gratitude to the many useful lessons we have taken to heart during our weary convalescence.

div.head: Report for 1906
div.p: The following is the general summary of the annual report of the Egyptian State Railways for the year 1906, presented to the Minister of Public Works by G.B. Macauley Bey, General Manager ; further particulars of the workings of the railway will be given in future issues:—

I have the honour to submit a report on the working of the Egyptian State Railways and Telegraphs for the year 1906. It may not be out of place here to mention the great lass which this Administration sustained by the death of Major Johnstone in September. The receipts in all branches have been satisfactory. The gross receipts of the Railways amounted to L.E. 3,257,600 ; the working expenses to LE. 1,839,643; leaving a net profit of LE.

418,067 ; being an increase of LE 91,395 over 1905. Twenty-two and a half million passengers were carried, giving a revenue of L.E. 1,398,546, being an increase of 12.7% in numbers and of 12.8 % in receipts.

Six and three quarter million tons of goods and half a million head of cattle have been carried for L K. 1,749,231, being an increase of 20.4% in tonnage and 5.8% in receipts. The disparity between the increases in tonnage and receipts is due to service transports which have been carried in much larger quantities than in 1905. The difficulties of the Sugar Company and the low prices ruling in the onion market have also affected the goods receipts. Taking the capital of the Railways at the figure fixed by Lord Farrer's Commission, the following table shows that the net earnings are increasing more rapidly than the interest in the fresh capital expended taken at 5% :-

In this connection it may be mentioned that a stock-taking and valuation are being made for the whole Railway to enable the capital value of the lines to be estimated with more accuracy. The passenger train kilometrage amounted to 8700000 an increase of 10.2% on the previous year, due to 39 additional trains being put into service. I regret to have to report two accidents to passenger trains resulting in the death of one passenger and slight injuries to eighteen others. The first of these was the derailment of an express at Palais de Koubbeh. The second was a collision between a goods train and a local passenger train at Mit Assas. The standard of punctuality has been well maintained on the whole - there are a certain number of unavoidable delays due to reductions in speed necessitated by the numerous engineering works for improvements which are now in hand. There is an increase in the proportion of expenditure lo gross receipts; this is partly due to a more correct method of accounting, and partly to the increased rates of pay which it has been necessary to give to the less highly paid officials in order to counterbalance the increased cost of living. The expert appointed to examine the system of audit and account reports favourably on the progress which has been made since his last visit ; there are still some points which require attention ; these are being taken in hand. A test audit section is being formed. As regards the question of staff generally, private companies are paying higher rates than the Government and it is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain good men. The only advantage which a Government can offer is a pension of some kind. At the same time the regulations for the Cadre are unsuitable for the majority of the railway staff. A Provident Fund is therefore being started which will lie applicable to men on the lower rates of pay as well as to men on the higher rates. The question of house rent at the larger centres is also becoming serious, especially for the less highly paid officials ; the only satisfactory way of dealing with this is to build quarters for the staff so that the Government can control the rents ; anything in the way of house allowance is unsatisfactory as the landlords continually raise rents. Every effort is being made to train men of our own staff to fill the higher vacancies as they occur, in order to avoid bringing in men from other railways. The Chief Mechanical Engineer's report shows an increase of 25 engines after deducting 18 old and useless engines from the stock and also seven engines which were sold. The total number of engines in service at the end of 1906 was 56.

The average age of engines in 1906 was 12 years as against 14 in 1905. Two hundred and thirty five engines underwent heavy repairs and 208 light repairs ; 233 engines had been fitted with the vacuum brake on 31st December 1906, 12 have been fitted with the front connection for this brake. The coal consumed by engines averages 104 kilogrammes per kilometre as against 109 kilogrammes in 1905. The number of coaching vehicles in service on 31st December 1906 was 1063. Daring the year, 109 vehicles were fitted with the vacuum brake bringing the total number of vehicles so fitted to 939. Four thousand and fifty-one vehicles have undergone repair». The number of goods wagons of all classes in service on 1st January, 1906, was 9152 ; 986 were added during the year, bringing the total up to 10,137 more are on order. 110 old wagons have-been sold. The question of rolling stock presents some difficulties. For 9 months of the year there is more than sufficient for all requirements but for the other three months there are not enough goods wagons. If there were sufficient for all demands during the busy season there would be a large number standing idle during the other nine months, which simply means so much capital locked up and not earning interest. Probably the best guide in considering whether to order new stock or not will lie the work which our existing stock is doing as compared with that of other similar lines. Meanwhile arrangements have been made to import as much of the railway coal and stores as possible, during the slack season. One hundred and fifty-six kilometres of main line have been renewed. One hundred and eighty- nine kilometres of line have been ballasted. Thirty-one kilometres of extra aiding accommodât ion have been added, 11 kilometres being in Gabbary Yard. Fifteen new passenger platforms and 10 new goods platforms have been built Five new turntables and 4 new weighbridges have been put in. Sixty-six kilo metres of fencing have been erected. The work of strengthening Benha bridge is proceeding satisfactorily.; it is expected to be finished this year ; several other bridges need strengthening to enable them to take heavier engines. A considerable amount of work has been done by the Land and Estate Office. The doubling of the Wasta Minieh section has been somewhat delayed by the late arrival of rails. Good progress has been made with the buildings oh this section ; these include quarters for 239 subordinate employees as well as houses for stationmastesa, station buildings offices, etc. The expropriation of land for the Defra Zifteh- Zagazig line is progressing ; it is hoped that all the necessary land will be in our possession before the end of 1907. Land is also being obtained for the line from Chebin-cl-Kanater to Abu-Zaabal ; work on this extension will probably begin in May, 1907. A deviation has been made at Abbassia at the request of the Sanitary Department.

Work on the improvements to Cairo Station and Yard is preceding satisfactorily ; the second goods shed has been completed and put into service. The new carriage shed is well in hand. More room is needed at Cairo for dealing with goods; steps are being taken to provide this. More accommodation is being provided at Gabbary, and a new covered goods station will shortly be opened near the Custom House. A large inwards goods depot and offices are under construction and will shortly be finished. New permanent way shops are being built. Land for extensions at Mansura has been acquired. The remodeling of Zagiuig Station has been almost completed. The work of Zifteh bridge is making good progress ; the brides over the canal and Nile at the Barrage will shortly be commenced. Thirty-five new signal cabins have been opened this year. The signaling of the lines is one of the most urgent works ; it involves the remodeling of many stations and will therefore take some considerable time. The Medical Department has done much good work. Nearly one thousand more candidates have been medically examined for admission to the service this year than in the previous year. The sick rate has increased owing epidemics of influenza and dengue fever. The Indemnity Committee, which was formed in March, has done much to lessen litigation in questions of personal injury. The receipts from the Telegraphs Administration have increased by L.E. 4377 but this figure does not accurately represent the results obtained by the year's work, which are really better than would appear from the above figure. Terminal and transit rates have been reduced, also the subvention to the Eastern Telegraph Company. The Railway now pays for railway telegrams sent by employees of the Telegraph Department. The number of commercial messages has increased by 15.3 percent over 1905 Two new telephone circuits between Alexandria and Cairo were built this year and handed over to the Telephone Company in November. Two more will lie built in 1907. There are now 3,094 kilometres of telephone line. Five hundred kilometres of new telegraph wire have been erected, besides a new line from Suez to Nakhi. 8 new offices have been opened. The reorganization of the Stores Department has been continued in 1906 with good results. The Indents and Sales branch has been transferred from the General Manager's office to Boulac. Although the weight of materials handled has been exceptionally large, the cost of handling has not increased in the same proportion. Better prices have been obtained from the sale of old material. All coal stocks have now been transferred from the Locomotive Department to the Stores Department.

div.head: EGYPT AND A PROTECTORATE
div.p: The "Telegraph" correspondent at Constantinople, in an interesting message regarding the views held in the capital on the subject of Britain's position in Egypt, a summary of which our London correspondent cabled on the 18th, says:

The impression cause» 1 here in political circles by the article published in the Egyptian paper "El Watan" with regard to a British Protectorate in Egypt, is that, logically, "El Watan" is right in asking that England should make some definite declaration as to her future course of action, as there is not the slight of doubt that the uncertainty in which the Egyptians have been left since the occupation is responsible for many of the difficulties which have arisen, and which might have been avoided it the exact position was known. The uncertainty of the position has given rise to hopes which are now disappointed. Those who gave themselves up to illusions which day by day they find arc» becoming less and less reliable, have become the enemies of the English, and wish, once for all, to know their exact intentions. But is it possible for England to satisfy them by adopting one of two solutions, that is, to leave Egypt or to establish a Protectorate People here are quite convinced she can do neither the one nor the other, for various reasons.

First of all, England has made on several occasions declarations to Europe that she had no intention of modifying in any way her in tentions towards Egypt, as shown on the first days of the occupation, and that she would maintain the same system of Government These in tentions have not only been recently shown again in the entente with France, but, it may be said, have been consecrated by that entente. Every successive Cabinet in England has held the same policy. England would not, therefore, simply perjure her. promises and word if she changed the actual state of affairs, but would certainly raise grave complications and possibly conflicts, which would be most undesirable in the present state of the Western nations.

Another reason which must be taken into consideration is that the Sultan, who, although he may be said to lie satisfied and reassured by the English policy in Egypt, would never allow that he is pleased to see «me of his provinces occupied by English troops, and as he was unable to resist, it has resigned himself to it. Any change, such as a Protectorate, would be most distasteful to him, as then he would lose all the feeling of suzerainty which satisfies him at present. At the present he is tranquil in feeling that England upholds his prestige as Sovereign, and does even more-she holds in heck the Khedive and the Egyptians, and he therefore is relieved from the fear they might rise and demand their independence, and detach themselves entirely from Turkey, which he is absolutely unable to prevent.

From the foregoing the only conclusion to lie arrived at is that, in spite of the logical reasoning of "El Watan," no change is possible in England's policy in Egypt. It is not impossible that England might one day put an end to her occupation, that is included in her programme, but she could only do so when she is certain that her interests and those of Egypt are not jeopardised in any way, and that day is too far off to lie thought of seriously at present.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET.
div.p: The following are the vessels of the Mediterranean Fleet which are expected to arrive at Alexandria on Finlay evening :—
Battleship "Queen", Admiral's Flag-Ship, Admiral Sir Charles Drury.
Battleship "Venerable", Vice-Admiral's Flag Ship, Prince Louis of Battenberg.
Armoured twin screw cruiser "Bacchante", Rear-Admirais Flag-Ship. Admiral Sir Henry Barry.
Battleship "Irresistible", Captain Lionel G. Tufnell
Battleship "Implacable", Captain George E. Patey, M.V.O.
Protected 2nd class cruiser Venus", Captain G. Francis Eyre.
Protected 2nd class cruiser "Minerva' Captain Henry J. L. Clarke.
Armoured twin screw cruiser "Lancaster' Captain Herbert L. Heath.
Annoured 1st class cruiser "Suffolk", Captain Rosslyn E Wemyss, M.V.O
Armoured twin screw cruiser "Aboukir Captain Claud A. W. Hamilton.
Protected 3rd class cruiser "Barham", Commander Murray F. Sueter.
The following are the tonnages and complement of the vessels :—

"Queen", tonnage f5,000, complement 789 "Venerable ", tonnage 15,000, complement 789 "Bacchante", tonnage 7,840, complement 700 "Irresistible", tonnage 15,000, complement 780 "Implacable", tonnage 15,000, complement 780 "Venus", tonnage 5,600, complement 450 "Minerva" tonnage 5,600, complement 437 "Lancaster" tonnage 9,800, complement 700 "Suffolk", tonnage 9,800, complement 700 "Aboukir", tonnage 12,000, complement 700 "Barham", tonnage 1,830, complement 180 Presuming that all these vessels are at full strength, the full complement of the fleet will therefore be 7,005 officers and men.

After leaving Alexandria the Mediterranean Fleet will call successively at Jaffa Beyront, Limassol, Rhodes, Marmarice, Smyrna, Mitylene, Thasos, Lemnos, Phalerum, Navarino, Platea and Corfu, and return to Malta about the 1st October.

div.head:
DEATH OF SIR E. STANTON
EX-CONSUL GENERAL IN EGYPT
div.p: The death is reported of Sir Edward Stanton, K.C.B., who was H.B.M.'s Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General in Egypt 1865 to 1876. He attended Ismail on his visit to England and in 1875 he signed the contract for the purchase of the Khedive's shares in the Suez Canal Company by England.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Boyle, the Oriental Secretary at the British Agency will take his annual leave from July 8th. He will return to Cairo at the end of September.
M. Girard, French Consul at Alexandria, and Mme Girard will leave on the 5th proxo. for Europe.
Mr. C. B. Clapcott, judge of the native courts of First Instance at Assiout has been transferred to Keneh, exchanging judgeships with Mr. A. C. McBarnet, who has been transferred to Assiout.

Captain E.J.F. Vaughan, Manchester Regiment, who is employed as s D. A. G. and Assistant Private Secretary to the Sirdar, has been transferred to the South Lancashire Regiment, on the reduction of the former regiment to two line battalions. Captain Vaughn remains with the Egyptian Army on transfer it is officially notified. He joined the Devonshire Regiment in 1896, and was promoted captain into the Manchesters in 1901 whilst serving on the staff in South Africa. He was with the Devons in Buller's advance into Ladysmith, was present at Colenso, Spion Kop, Togela Heights and Pieter's Hill, where he was wounded, and on the staff saw further fighting in Natal,the Transvaal (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with six clasps, King's medal with two clasps). Captain Vaughan has served with the Egyptian Army since August, 1902.

Brevet Colonel Sir C. Fergusson, Bart., Grenadier Guards, who was so long and honourably associated with the Khedive's Army, has been selected for the appointment of Brigadier General, General Staff, Irish Comma ml, in succession to Brigadier General F. Hammer sley, and will take up his duties on the 1st October next. His many friends in Egypt will be glad to hear of this gallant officer's advancement.
The death is announced at Abano near Padua of Chevalier Iona, formerly Italian Consul at Alexandria and Port Said. He was born in 1857.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hui a 11 h 1/2
Londres ayant haussé, notre marché a suivi le mouvement, tout eu restant un peu en arrière.

Quant aux affaires, bien qu'elle* aient été plus nombreuses que les jours précédents, elles n'en demeurent pas moins clairsemées et de lieu d'importance. Elles ont porte principalement sur l'Agricole, la National Bank, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier, les Estates, l'Urbaine, l'Union Foncière et l'United.
Ce sont l'Agricole et la National Bank qui, comme à Londres, bénéficient de la plus forte reprise. Elle remontent respectivement de 7 3/16 et 17 1/16 à 7 9/16 et 18 1/2.

En reprise également la Ramleh de 5 à 5 1/8, la Sait and Soda de 16/9 à 17, les Nungovich Hotels de U à 14 1/2, la Delta Land de 1 5/8 à 1 11/16, la Khédivial Mail de 4 1/8 à 4 1/4 l'action et de 21/6 à 22 l'ordinary, la Land Bank de 6 15/16 à 7, l'Urbaine de 3 7/8 à 4, l'Union Foncière île 4 3/8 à 4 5/8, le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 à 4 1 16 et lu Rauque d'Orient de 113 à 114
La Banque d'Athènes, qui avait subi une forte dépression, reprend de 109 à 113 acheteurs et les Estates de 11/16 à 7/8 acheteurs.

Les nouvelles émissions profitent aussi de l'amélioration générale L'United reprend de 3 8 à 7/16 l'action et de 2 à 2 1,2 la fondateur, les Ritz Hotels de 5/8 à 11/16, la Levico de 3/8 à 7/16 et la Sednaoui Zariffa de 3 à 3 1/2 l'action et de 5 à 9 la fondateur.

11 n'a rien été fait en Cassa di Sconto. Vendeurs et acheteurs attendent évidemment d'être fixés sur la situation exacte de cette banque et sur l'avenir qui lui est réservé. Il est indispensable pour cela d'attendre la publication du bilan.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres s'est maintenu à 4 pour cent Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé, vendredi passé, de 1/8 à 83 1/2 et d'autant le lendemain à 83 5/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 100 1/4. Vendredi, la National Bank a encore perdu 3/4 k 16 3/4 ; samedi, elle est remontée d'une demi-livre à 17 1/4. L'Agricole a rétrogradé de 1/4 à 17 1/4. La Daira Sanieh a reculé de 1/2 livre, vendredi, à 12 3/4 pour rattraper 1/8, samedi, à 12 7/8. La Delta Light a rétrogradé de 1/2 livre à 8 1/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien, en perte de 19 franc* vendredi a 648, a regagné le len demain 8-francs à 656. La Banque d'Athènes a laissé 6 francs a 114.

Par suite de l'amélioration signalée samedi à Londres et à Paris, notre marché de* valeurs a fait, ce matin, assez bonne contenance. L'activité n'a pas été, il est vrai, remarquable (il n'y a eu en tout que 12 transactions) mais l'animation a été vive d'un bout à l'autre de la séance. Si l'on n'a pas repris confiance, on s'est généralement montré plus rassuré, et les offres ont été moins nombreuses. En réalité, il y eu reprise sur an certain nombre de valeurs bien que les cours inscrits aujourd'hui présentent pour la plupart une moins value sur ceux indiqués au tableau officiel de la dernière séance. Cette particularité tient à la décision saugrenue, prise vendredi passé par le Comité, de ne pas modifier la cote de la veille.

Cette légère amélioration locale est elle appelée à se maintenir î II est difficile de se prononcer sur une question si délicate. Tout dé pend du genre de solution qui sera donné ù la grosse affaire de k Cassa di Sconto. Il faut attendre pour cela les nouvelles qui nous par viendront d'Alexandrie, qui sont-arrivés ce matin les deux délégués de l'Union Bank de Vienne. Pour l'instant, un indice rassurant, c'est que, sur la demande commune des avocats des deux parties, le tribunal des référés a été prié de surseoir provisoirement au prononcé de l'ordonnance relative à la nomination, requise d'urgence par l'Union Bank, d'un séquestre judiciaire qui serait chargé de la garde, a la Cassa di Sconto, des titres et effets formant la garantie de la Banque viennoise. Apparemment, celle-ci s'est rendu compte qu'en exigeant une telle mesure, elle portait atteinte à son propre crédit Toujours est il que des incidents variés peuvent se produire d'ici au 2 Juillet prochain, date à laquelle est convoquée l'assemblée extraordinaire-des actionnaires de la Cassa di Sconto.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, lu National a clôturé à 16 15/16 et l'Agricole à 7 3/16-1/4. La Cassa di Sconto a été ramenée à 45-50. Le Comptoir Financier a été marqué £ 3 et sa part de fondateur 2 nominal. La Société Générale Egyptienne a été cotée 240 et sa part 46.

Le Crédit Foncier a été inscrit à 665, nominal, et la Daira à 12 3 4. L'Enterprise and Development a été fixée à 8 3/4. Lea Allotments ont fléchi a 1 5/8, les Héliopolis a 245 et leur part à 9, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire à 188.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich, très manipulés, ont été poussés à 13 1/2. Les Egyptian ont été marqués 4 7/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a clôturé à 1 5/8, les Estates à 0 11/16 et leur part à 3, les New Egyptian à 14 sh. 6 et les Oasis à 0 3/8-7/16.

L assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. a été tenue samedi passé à la National Bank of Egypt au Caire. Elle a approuvé les comptes et bilan de l'exercice clos le 31 Mars 1907 et fixé le dividende à 3 shellings par action, payable, dit-on, à partir du 1er Juillet prochain.
Dans le discourt qu'il a prononcé, le président de l'assemblée, M. Williamson, a ex-
posé comme suit les perspectives d'avenir de la Société :

"La crise financière qui sévit en Egypte coupe, du reste, en Europe et en Amérique, aura un jour sa fin. Avec le retour de la confiance renaîtra l'activité sur le marché des terrains de construction. Je ne veux pas dire qu'il faut s'attendre a un proche retour des hauts prix pratiqués l'année dernière pour certains terrains de la banlieue ; mais des terrains aussi bon marché que ceux que possède notre Compagnie seront toujours vendus avec de beaux bénéfices. Un coup d'œil jeté sur notre rapport vous montrera qu'au 31 Mars 1907 nous avions une superficie de 1,573,774 mètres carrés revenant k une somme totale de LE. 179,061, ce qui fait une moyenne de P.E. 11 1/2 ou, avec 40% à ajouter pour les routes, de P.E. 16 par mètre carré. Dans ces chiffres sont compris environ 60,000 mètres carrés sis dans les villes du Caire, Tantah, etc., lesquels, même à la mauvaise époque actuelle, pourraient être vendus à un prix moyen de plusieurs foi* supérieur k leur coût."

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Compagnie Agricole du Nil est convoquée pour le 16 Juillet prochain au siège social à Anvers. A Tordre du jour : rapport du conseil d'administration ; présentation des comptes et bilan au 8! Mars 1907 ; fixation du dividende.
Le dépôt des titres au Caire doit être effectué à la Banque Impériale Ottomane, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank où à la Société Générale Egyptienne.

Les recettes de la Delta Light Railways Co. pour la semaine au 15 Juin courant se sont élevées à LE 4,463 contre 3,8/9 en 1906, soit en augmentation de LE. 635. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1907 se chiffrent par LE 51,335 contre 41,298 pour l'exercice précédent, soit en majoration de LE 10,037.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head:
THE WINE CRISIS
Prospects of Concilation. Clemenceau and Albert.

div.p: M. Albert earnestly disclaimed political motives and lagged M. Clemenceau to show mercy and release his colleagues thus to restore calm M. Clemenceau firmly refused to do so, and M. Albert finally promised to return to the South and persuade his fellow citizens to return to the paths of loyalty. Meanwhile his arrest has been suspended, though it is understood that he will eventually surrender. This is regarded as a step in the direction of conciliation Crowds at Narbonne received the news with cheers. (Reuter)
The 17th Regiment at Beziers has entrained, under a strong guard, for another district.
M. Clemenceau replied to a deputation of vine growers that all municipalities must resume their duties before the prisoners would he released. (Reuter)
M. Albert has returned. The committee, in consideration of the law and the vagueness of M. Clemenceau's promises, has decided to continue the struggle on pacific lines.
The 17th Infantry has been removed and has left for Gap. (Havas)

div.head: House Of Lords. The Premier's Statement

div.p: House of Commons. Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman moved the Lords' resolution. He announced that a Bill would eventually be submitted providing that a bill which had three times passed the House of Commons should become law despite the lords' rejection. It would also provide for private conferences of equal numbers of Lords and Commoners after each rejection with a view to a compromise being arranged.

He scathingly criticized the difference of attitude adopted by the lords under the Liberal and Conservative regimes and declared that Mr. Balfour left no doubt of the Lords using utilized as an annexe to the Unionist party. (Reuter)
Five of the soldiers who mutinied at Kief on the 19th June have been shot (Reuter)
The chiefs of the parties have chosen M. Weiss Kichner, a Social Christian, as candidate for the Reichsrath presidency. (Haras)
In a railway accident at Vlade-Cancasia, 23 carriages were smashed. 7 persons were killed and 200 injured. (Havas)

The Minister of Finance announced the that financial outlook was most favourable. The treasury would be able to dispense with the internal loan of 8,000,000 euros for which provision had been made in the budget. (Reuter)
Salar-ed-Dowleh, on receiving assurance that his life would be spared surrendered to the Governor of Hamadan. (Reuter)

div.head: PRINCE VON BUELOW. Opposing Ministers Retire.

div.p: Prince von Buelow's position has been greatly strengthened by the retirement of Count Posadowski Welmer, Imperial Secretary of the Interior, and Dr. Studt, Prussian Minister of Works, following a special journey of Prince von Buelow to Kiel to see the Emperor. Both ministers were opposed to the Chancellor's breach with the Centre and his reliance on the hybrid majority of Conservatives and Liberals. The former minister was frequently mentioned as a candidate of the Eulenhurg clique for the Chancellorship. (Reuter)

div.head: CYPRUS
A summer resort for Egypt. The attractions of Troodos.
div.p: (Second Article)

The heats of midsummer are upon us, the burning soil with its parched vegetation radiates heat, the lifeless atmosphere stifles one, the rest tor business and pleasure alike has lost its edge, and nature drags on dully from day to day, limp and listless. Circumstances have conspired to prevent the annual flight to Europe, but many an Anglo-Egyptian official could manage to escape for a month if only there were a cool, healthy resort within quick access of Cairo.

Has he never heard of Mt. Troodos in Cyprus? If not, let him learn that its fresh, healthgiving breezes have fanned the cheeks of not a few of his brother officials, that every year its praises are sung anew and fresh visitors arrive to inhale its invigorating air and revive their flagging energies.

Mt. Troodos rises to an altitude of 6,400 feet above the sea level. It is the highest point of the long mountain range which extends east and west along the southern portion of the island. It may be reached now in various ways. The recently constructed railway line from Nicosia to Morphou enables the traveller from Nicosia to evade the long drive through the plains by taking the train to Avlona and driving from there. Many, however, may still prefer to drive all the way and avoid the discomfort of changing from carriage to train and vice versa. By making an early morning start much of the tedious plain can be traversed before the heat has become intolerable. The latter half of the journey is delightful to those Coming from sunbaked Nicosia or Cairo. The winding road is one long ascent for some 6,000 feet, and the eye is fascinated and all one's senses are soothed by the mountain scenery as it unfolds itself hour after hour. The low scrub lias long since been left behind and now gives place to elm and alder, pine cypress, walnut and oak, while as we approach the top, arbutus and ilex, and bracken also, clothe the mountain sides. Running stream* of water, with oleander, white and pink, in bloom, lend additional charm and proclaim the proximity of snow, which, indeed, may yet be found in the "snowpits" above us, and from whence it is conveyed through the summer on the backs of donkeys to distort Nicosia, where until this year it has served as a substitute for ice. As we look upwards flic towering mountain summits with their waning pines, beckon us on, as it were, to the very sky itself whose deep blue dome encloses all.

Galata is usually the halting place for carriages ascending from the northern of Nicosia side. It is unfortunate that, seeing how much traffic passes through this village during the summer months, no accommodation worthy the name lias yet been provided. It is one of the most glaring instances of want of enterprise in catering to the travelling public that the Island presents, for there is scarcely another village, frequented as this is, which does not make some attempt to provide for the ordinary needs of travelers. Let us hope that Galata has this year awoke to a sense of its importance.

The remaining fifteen miles of road are gratefully shaded by overhanging nicks, and the lengthening shadows and decline of day combined with the cooler temperature, bring a sense of relief and freshness. Added to this the glimpses we catch of mountain peaks on a level with, or even below ourselves, enable us to realize the height we have reached and the new climate we have found. At about five miles from our journey's end we pass a roadside fountain and cattle trough, erected by the late High Commissioner, Sir W. F. Haynes Smith, hearing the appropriate legend carved upon it "He sendeth the springs into the rivers which run among the hills.
Here we are able to refresh ourselves with a draught of pure, cold, spring water and bathe our hands and feet in the gushing stream which receives many a grateful benediction both from man and beast
The entire road journey from Nicosia is some 11 to 12 hours : if by train to Avlona, some 2 to 3 hours less.

The usual route for visitors from Egypt is via Limassol, where one arrives by the weekly mail boat at 6 p.m on Friday. The Nicosia and the Troodos hotels are both fairly clean and comfortable. Though Troodos is only 20 miles off as the crow flies, the windings of the carriage road double the distance, which is covered in 10 to 11 hours.

The question of accommodation on Troodos is not so easily settled. Until the last year or two, practically the only visitors there, were Government officials to whom huts or tent* were allotted by the Government, or who owned their own Difficulty is experienced in obtaining leave to pitch a camp, a* the ground belongs either to the Government or to the War Office. A small hotel has been opened the last year two, managed by Mr. Najem floury of Limassol. The sender is good and the situation convenient. Of late years also a camp has been formed by a Miss Young, of Nicosia, frequented by English officias who wish for a short holiday and who have no huts, and by visitors from elsewhere. This camp meets all one's requirements, a* by having a private sitting room tent and using the common dining room one is able to enjoy privacy and at the same time be spared the trouble of arranging for camp furniture, and the difficulties of house keeping.

The station of Troodos consists of two encampments : the one situated on the higher elevation is the military camp, where the small detachment of troops some 100 to 150 strong, which forms the island garrison, is always quartered during summer. A number of civilians' huts and tents are now found congregated on the adjacent land. Here are the hotel and Miss Young's camp, as also soldiers recreation room, which is used as a church room, and the few stores and 'tradesmen who cater for the camp. The tennis courts are also close by. The whole of this encampment is generally described as 'the top'. About a mile down the mountain we come to the other encampment. This is the site of the Government offices, around which are grouped the tents of the officials attached to the secretariat, while half-way between the two camps is Government Cottage.

The views from almost every hut or tent, whether on 'the top' or lower down are glorious embracing a wide stretch of hilly country, composed of sharp ravines, jagged peaks, forest and fell. The upper camp faces north, and from it one can get glimpses of the far distant plain lying shimmering in the heat, and 'unrelieved by any foliage of sufficient importance to lie seen from this height. The lower camp looks south towards the sea, and, 20 miles off we can just distinguish the town of Limassol, and, to the west of it, the huge Salt Lake gleaming white and brilliant even at this distance. For two-third* the intervening space the mountain's form a long series of folds and undulations and rocky declivities gradually sloping seawards, and the ever-changing lights and shadows as they fall on height or hollow add intensity amd interest to the picture.

The life on Troodos for the non-official visitor or official 'on leave' is for the first few days a delightful 'dolce far niente,' during which his senses will yield themselves to a delicious languor. When this stage has passed, the effects of the cool, invigorating air begin to tell. He will wake betimes with a thrill and sense of exhilaration, the appetite returns and his whole energies are reinforced.

To a pedestrian the place offers an endless variety of delightful walks. Good mules can be had for from 2/- to 3/- a day : carriages can only be used on the main road. Every lay fresh excursions can be made to some delightful spot or other. Besides the day excursions, there are two or three days trips to be made. One such is to the famous Kykko Monastery, distant about 15 miles, across the moat gloriously will and broken country. The road lies for a great part through the pine forests which extend throughout this region, and in the clearer spaces the hardy villagers seek to wrest from these almost inaccessible heights a precarious living out of the vine. Ample accommodation is obtainable at the Monastery, where simple food is provided Visitors should, at all cost, take camp beds, and are advised also to take any small "comforts" they deem necessary. No charge is made, but it is usual when staying at these monasteries to place a donation in the church box before leaving, which should fairly cover one's board and lodging. Complaints are occasionally heard that very 'nominal" contributions are made, a practice which in the interests of tourists should be discouraged.
Platres is a pretty little village about 5 miles along the road from Troodos to Limassol.

Those who desire a less bracing climate may prefer this place, which is growing in popularity and where a number of picturesque little cottages are being let for the summer, though the supply still falls short of the demand.

The monastery of Trooditissa, Mesapotamos, and the apple growing village of Prodromos, the highest village in the island, are favorite places for picnics. Longer excursions include thé fertile Marathassa valley. One of the chief of the Marutheft's villages is Kalopanayioti, noted for its sulphur springs, which, although now highly esteemed by the natives, may one day acquire a wider fame. When here, the visitor should not fail to see the monastery and its ancient little chapel with its frescoed walls.

Mt. Olympus, which, as the name indicates, is the very topmost summit of the Troodos, range, is within an easy walk of the upper camp and from its lofty height one obtains a magnificent panorama. In the hazy distance nearly 40 miles off in a direct line, one can just see Nicosia, a faintly dark blur on the plain, while facing us, far down beyond the foothills is the Bay of Morphon, the western extremity of the isUnd. To the west and south the eye can sweep the coast, or the hilly ground which borders it, almost as far as Larnaca.

Much of the social life of the camp is necessarily concentrated into the hours from 4 p.m. onwards—when the officials are free and the two tennis courts are besieged. Occasional cricket matches and sports are got up by, for or with the troops. Concerts and theatricals are given towards the latter end of the season, and every week an afternoon reception, with games, is held at Government Cottage.

Ordinary provisions at very slight increased prices are generally obtainable from the provision dealers who open stores there for the season, and fresh supplies are constantly received from Limassol, while fruit, vegetables, poultry, and eggs are brought in from the neighboring villages. Church services are held ever)* Sunday 'Doming and evening, and the professional advice and attendance of the military doctor are at the disposal of the civilians.
Anglo-Egyptians who wish for a quiet, restful holiday, in pure air, and mountain scenery within easy reach and at moderate expense, will find in Troodos all that they seek.

div.head: Egypt 100 Years Ago. The Battle of Rosetta.
div.p: The following extract is from the "Times" of June 16, 1807, and was quoted by our contemporary last Monday :

Our loss in the second action in Egypt, there is reason to fear, was greater than is admitted in the Official Dispatch. Instead of 1,000 killed and wounded, we understand it amounts to full 1500. The enemy, it is said, exclusive of their infantry, had nearly 3000 cavalry with them. Under cover of one of those thick jogs which often prevail in the vicinity of die Lower Nile, the latter approached General .Stewart's detachment without being observed. Our troops, we understand, were in consequence reduced to the necessity of cutting their way through the enemy. Out of 2500 that were engaged in the second affair, not more than 1,000, it is said, proceeded in extricating themselves. There is an expression in General Frazer's second letter, which induces us to believe that the detachment sent against Rosetta was for some time envelop by tho enemy. The second battle, according to private accounts, took place on the 19th of April ; and yet, in his letter of the 64th, he states, "the troops under General Stewart are only noir on their march to Alexandria." How did they pass the intervening time? There appears to have been a most deplorable deficiency of information among our people. The misfortunes which we have to lament in this Expedition seem to have arisen from a want of foresight in the Commander of it.

Wednesday, June 17. It is stated, in an article from Warsaw, that Alexandria has been evacuated by our troops. We hope this is not the case. General Fraser, we believe, was inclined to do so ; but he assuredly would not take upon himself the weighty responsibility of such a measure, except to escape certain extermination, or to avoid an alternative almost as horrible, that of becoming prisoners to the Turks. We are bound, however, by recent experience, to treat this rumor with some respect It was from the Continent that we first received the news of our miscarriage before Constantinople, and of our reverses in Egypt.

div.head: Sport and Play. Cricket.
Railway Institute versus Army Service Corps.
div.p: The clubs met for the first time this season, at Ghezireh Badrane on Friday last. The Institute won the toss and batted first Rev. Burns and Windsor went to the wickets but after a single bad been obtained the latter had his middle stump bowled out of the ground. The Institute batsmen showed themselves to be greatly in need of practice, the whole side being disposed of for 69. The Service Corps made as bad a start as the home team, Baxter being bowled with only 3 on the board. Mr. Jordan and Sergt. West then put a different aspect on the game. The former played very nice cricket, while the latter defended stub bornly and 44 were scored before Jordan was bowled. This looked like a defeat for the homesters but mainly owing to some smart field ing and splendid wicket keeping by W. B. Davies four men were dismissed for an additional 3 runs. The seventh wicket fell at 52 but Fowles and Hall played very well and when 60 was hoisted the game looked an easy thing for the visitors. Rev. Bums who had been bowling splendid had Fowles caught, and clean bowled Hall and Martin, the Institute gaining a close victory by 7 runs : -

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire. Emission.
div.p: De 30,000 Actions de "Jouissance" Nouvelles
Dont la souscription est reserve a Messieurs les porteurs d'Actions actuelles de la Societe, de Capital eu de Jouissance indistinctement
Ces 30,000 Actions font partie des 48,000 Actions dont la creation a ete autorise par l'Assemblee Generale du 5 Juin 1907.

En vertu d'une décision de l'Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire du 5 Juin 1907, et (l'Autorisation Ministérielle du 23 Mai 1907, le Conseil d'Administration de la Société Anonyme des Eaux du Caire émet, en augmentation des 272,000 Actions de Jouissance actuellement existantes, trente mille Actions de Jouissance nouvelles, dont la souscription est réservée aux porteurs d'Actions actuelles de Capital on de Jouissance indistinctement, sur la base d'une Action nouvelle pour onze Actionsactuelles sans attribution de fraction.(*)

Ces nouvelles Actions de Jouissance auront les mêmes droits que celles actuellement ex i.s tan tes, sous cette seule réserve que, devant être libérées pour cette année, suivant les conditions ci-après, de moitié seulement de leur prix d'émission et à la date du 1er Juillet, elles n'auront droit, comme dividende de l'exercice en cours, qu'à un quart du coupon entier de l'exercice.

Des certificats provisoires nominatifs seront délivrés après paiement de la première moitié du prix d'émission fixé ci après, et seront échangés contre les titres définitifs au porteur après paiement de l'autre moitié du dit prix. Ces titres définitifs seront numérotés de 272.000 à 302.000.
Le prix d'émission est fixé à 180 frs. par Action, soit P.T. 094,r, payables comme suit ;
Fin. 90 soit P.T. 347, en souscrivant
Frs. 90 soit P.T. 347, le 1er Janvier 1908 Les souscriptions seront reçues :

au CAIRE, au Siège de la Société, avenue de Bouloc, à ALEXANDRIE, au Crédit Lyonnais, les 25, 26, 27 et 28 Juin, de 9 heures du matin à midi. Passé le 28 Juin midi, aucune souscription ne sera plus reçue.
Les Actions oui ne seraient pas souscrites lans le délai ci dessus fixé, seront elles mêmes reserves aux porteurs d'actions actuelles.

Indépendamment donc de leur droit irréductible tie souscrire à 1 Action nouvelle pour 11 actuelles, Messieurs les porteurs d'Actions actuelles, de Capital ou de Jouissance, même si le nombre de leurs actions est inférieur à onze, auront la faculté de souscrire dins le même délai sus-indiqués aux actions qui pourraient éventuellement être ainsi disponibles a l'expiration du dit, délai.
Les dites souscriptions aux Actions éventuellement disponibles seront servies au prorata les demandes, étant toujours bien entendu pie, l'Action étant indivisible, les fractions seront négligées.
Pour ces souscriptions aux actions éventuellement disponibles, le prix d'émission de Frs. 180 soit P.T. 694,35 sera payable comme, suit :
Frs. 20 soit Js.T. 77,15 en souscrivant,
Frs. 70 soit P.T. 270,025 à la répartition,
Frs. 90 soit P.T. 347,175 le 1er Janvier 1908.

Messieurs les intéressés pourront se procurer au Siège de la Société ainsi que (fans les bureaux du Crédit Lyonnais, des formules de bulletins de souscriptions, tant ]x>ur la souscription sur la base de 1 action nouvelle par 11 actuelles, que pour la souscription aux actions éventuellement disponibles.
Tout bulletin de souscription devra être accompagné :
1st de la présentation du reçu dur versement exigible ;
2nd de la présentation des titres d'actions actuelles en vertu desquels le droit de souscription est exercé, titres qui seront frappés l'une estampille jour constater l'exercice du dit droit
En cas de retard dans les versements, il y aura lieu de plein droit à l'application de l'article 11 des statuts ainsi conçu :
Art 11. — A défaut de versement aux époques déterminées, l'intérêt court de plein droit à la charge de l'actionnaire, à raison de six pour cent par an, pour chaque jour de retard.
Le retardataire est mis en demeure d'effectuer ses paiements par un avis inséré dans un des journaux désignés à l'article 8 : cet avis indique les numéros des actions en retard

Faute der l'actionnaire de se libérer dans le délai d'un mois et sans qu'il soit nécessaire de recourir à aucune formalité de justice, ni d'ajouter À ce laps d'un mois aucun délai en raison des distances, les actions en retard seront vendues publiquement sur duplicata, dans la tonne (pi indiquera le Conseil d'administration, le tout sans préjudice du droit (pie la Société conserve de poursuivre personnel lement l'actionnaire en retard.

Les titres primitifs des actions ainsi vendues sont nuis de plein droit En conséquence, toute action qui ne porte pas la mention régulière des versements qui ont du être opérés cesse d'être admissible à la négociation et au transfert.

div.head: Extrait des Statuts
div.p: Art. 6.— Le capital social est de huit millions cinq cent mille francs, et divisé en soixante huit mille actions de cent vingt cinq francs chacune, dites "actions de capital."
Art 13.—Indépendamment des 68,000 actions de capital mentionnées ci-dessus à l'art.6, il est créé 272.000 actions de jouissance sans valeur nominale.
Chaque action de capital donne droit à l'intérêt de 4% et au remboursement, spécifiés aux articles 20 et 21 ci-après.
Chaque action de jouissance donne droit à une part proportionnelle :
1. Dans le solde des bénéfices nets, aux termes du No. 3 de l'article 20 d-après.
2. Dans toutes les valeurs composant l'actif social, après complet remboursement des actions de capital.
Toutes les actions, soit de capital, soit de jouissance, ont, pour les attributions relatives à l'administration et pour le vote aux Assemblées générales, les mêmes droite.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie. Avis.
div.p: La Municipalité mot en adjudication les travaux de construction d'une annexe au Palais Municipal.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.Eg Quatre-Cents (400).
Icahier des charges est déposé au Bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 9 Juillet 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : " Soumission pour travaux d'une annexe au Palais Municipal."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 9 Juillet 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Alexandrie, le 17 Juin 1907.
L'Administrateur, 35200-3-3 (Signé.) W. P. Chataway.
Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs. AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat' a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'à partir du 25 courant, un bureau télégraphique sera ouvert à Mansourah ligne de Rosette, pour l'échange des Télégrammes en langues Européennes.
Le Caire, le 21 Juin 1907. 30525-2-2
AVIS

L'Administration des Télégraphes de l'Etat attire l'attention du public sur le fait que des télégrammes sont souvent retardés ou même ne sont pas remis à leur destinataire à cause de l'insuffisance des adresses.
Tou{s les télégrammes devraient être adressés de façon à pouvoir être délivrés sans que des recherches soient nécessaires.
